--- Andreas Heilwagen <andreas.heilwagen@...> wrote:
>Can you send the patch to me? :)
>I'd like to include it into JUnitX<BR>

Boy, is this embarassing. The guy who made the change removed the
source rather than archiving it. I just went in to reproduce the change
and discovered the junit authors were there before I was. In junit (3.4
at least) there is a properties file (~/junit.properties  with "~"
being the Java "user.home" property). If you set maxmessage in that
file (a line with "maxmessage=5000" for example), it will override the
default. I've got it set to 5000 now.

The only obvious enhancement would be to have maxmessage=-1 mean
infinite.

Patch for that (against junit 3.4):

$ diff -c junit/runner/BaseTestRunner.java.orig
junit/runner/BaseTestRunner.java
*** junit/runner/BaseTestRunner.java.orig       Mon Dec 18 15:27:31
2000
--- junit/runner/BaseTestRunner.java    Mon Dec 18 15:32:40 2000
***************
*** 74,80 ****
         * Truncates a String to the maximum length.
         */
        public static String truncate(String s) {
!               if (s.length() > fMaxMessage)
                        s= s.substring(0, fMaxMessage)+"...";
                return s;
        }
--- 74,80 ----
         * Truncates a String to the maximum length.
         */
        public static String truncate(String s) {
!               if ((fMaxMessage > 0) && (s.length() > fMaxMessage))
                        s= s.substring(0, fMaxMessage)+"...";
                return s;
        }

Regards,

Rob
